list.name: Changes
list.comment:
feat: Add VeloCli as the main entry point for the CLI
This commit introduces the `VeloCli` class, which serves as the main entry point for the Velocity CLI.
It utilizes Picocli to define the command structure and options:
- Provides a detailed description of Velocity's purpose, features, and roadmap. - Lists supported project types and example usage scenarios. - Includes subcommands for `create`, `add-feature`, and `add-component` (to be implemented). - Handles verbose output and error reporting.
This establishes the foundation for the Velocity CLI, allowing users to interact with the tool and execute various commands.

task.summary: Default task
Initial Commit
chore(deps): Add JGit dependency.
chore(deps): Add picocli dependency.
chore(deps): Add jackson-databind dependency.
chore(build tool): Update build tool version to 8.11 from 8.10.2
feat: Add a resource loader
feat: Add Native image compilation and modularize in gradle
feat: Add Native image compilation and modularize in gradle
feat: Add Native image compilation configuration. chore(deps): Update native image plugin to version 0.10.4 from 0.10.3
feat: Add Native image compilation configuration.
chore(deps): Update org.javamodularity.moduleplugin dependency from 1.8.1p to 1.8.15.

refactor: Rename package from velo to velocity
This commit renames the base package from `inc.nomard.velo` to `inc.nomard.velocity`.
This change affects the following packages:
- `inc.nomard.velo.cli` is renamed to `inc.nomard.velocity.cli` - `inc.nomard.velo.exception` is renamed to `inc.nomard.velocity.exception` - `inc.nomard.velo.model` is renamed to `inc.nomard.velocity.model` - `inc.nomard.velo.templating` is renamed to `inc.nomard.velocity.templating` - `inc.nomard.velo.validator` is renamed to `inc.nomard.velocity.validator` - `inc.nomard.velo` is renamed to `inc.nomard.velocity`

chore: Rename root project
Rename the root project from 'VeloCraft' to 'Velocity'. This change is reflected in the `settings.gradle` file, updating the `rootProject.name` property.

refactor: Rename module to 'velocity'
This commit renames the Java module from 'velo' to 'velocity'.
This change affects all package exports and open statements in the `module-info.java` file, reflecting the new module name.

refactor: Rename velo to velocity
This commit renames the project from 'velo' to 'velocity'. This includes updating the main module name, main class name, and docker image name in the build.gradle file.

feat: Add GitignoreTemplates class
This commit introduces a new class `GitignoreTemplates` to manage .gitignore templates for different project types.
The class provides a `forProjectType` method to retrieve the appropriate template based on the project type. It currently includes templates for Spring Boot and Flutter, with a default template for other project types.

feat: Add Git initialization functionality
This commit introduces the ability to initialize a Git repository within a newly created project.
The `GitInitializer` class is responsible for:
- Creating a Git repository using JGit. - Creating a `.gitignore` file based on the project type. - Setting up the initial Git configuration (e.g., `autocrlf`, `eol`). - Creating an initial commit with a default message. - Optionally adding a remote repository and pushing the initial commit.
This change allows users to have a version-controlled project from the start, facilitating collaboration and tracking changes.

feat: Add ParameterExceptionHandler
This commit introduces a custom parameter exception handler, `ParameterExceptionHandler`, which implements `CommandLine.IParameterExceptionHandler`.
The handler intercepts parameter exceptions during command-line parsing and provides user-friendly error messages. It prints the error message in red and suggests using `--help` for more information. It also respects the configured exit code for invalid input.

feat: Add create command
This commit introduces the `create` command to the CLI, enabling users to create new projects.
The command supports the following options:
- `-t`, `--type`: Specifies the project type (required). - `-n`, `--name`: Sets the project name (defaults to "new-project"). - `-p`, `--path`: Specifies the target directory (defaults to "."). - `--git`: Initializes a Git repository. - `--git-branch`: Sets the default Git branch name (defaults to "main"). - `--git-remote`: Specifies the Git remote URL. - `--push`: Pushes to the remote after initialization.

feat: Add `add-feature` command to CLI
This commit introduces a new CLI command, `add-feature`, which aims to add new features to existing projects.
The command takes the feature name as a required argument and optionally accepts a project path using the `-p` or `--path` flag (defaulting to the current directory).
While the implementation is still pending, this commit sets the foundation for future functionality related to adding features to existing projects.

feat: Add `add-component` command
This commit introduces a new CLI command `add-component` to add a new component to an existing feature.
It takes the feature name and component name as parameters, and an optional `--path` option to specify the project path.

feat: Add VeloExecutionStrategy
This commit introduces a custom execution strategy, `VeloExecutionStrategy`, for handling command execution and error reporting.
It catches `VeloException` and prints the error code and message to the console. For other exceptions, it prints a generic error message and the stack trace.
This strategy ensures that Velo-specific errors are handled gracefully and provides consistent error reporting for the user.

feat: Add VeloCli as the main entry point for the CLI
This commit introduces the `VeloCli` class, which serves as the main entry point for the Velocity CLI.
It utilizes Picocli to define the command structure and options:
- Provides a detailed description of Velocity's purpose, features, and roadmap. - Lists supported project types and example usage scenarios. - Includes subcommands for `create`, `add-feature`, and `add-component` (to be implemented). - Handles verbose output and error reporting.
This establishes the foundation for the Velocity CLI, allowing users to interact with the tool and execute various commands.
